newsitem.title: USA: Panel holds hearing on Calif. bullet train plan.
newsitem.headline: Panel holds hearing on Calif. bullet train plan.

text.p: A California state commission Tuesday convened its first public hearing on a multi-billion dollar proposal to build a high-speed rail system between San Francisco and Los Angeles.

Cost estimates for the proposed bullet train range from $11.9 billion to $16.8 billion, depending on the technology that would be used. Extensions to San Diego, Sacramento and San Jose could push the cost up to $25.8 billion.
To help pay for the massive project, bonds would likely be sold, backed by either gasoline or sales taxes or a combination of the two, commission officials said.

The Intercity High Speed Rail Commission, which has been reviewing bullet train proposals and funding options, heard testimony in San Francisco Tuesday from local residents and elected officials about the proposal. In the coming weeks, public hearings in Los Angeles and Fresno will also be held.
By late December, the commission was expected to issue a final report to the state Legislature and Gov. Pete Wilson about whether a bullet train would be feasible in California.
In a draft report issued earlier this year, the commission concluded that a high-speed rail system was feasible and would boost the California economy.
If approved by the state, the train could start operating as early as 2005, said Daniel Leavitt, executive director of the commission.

Under the high-speed rail plan being considered, commuters could travel the 412 miles from San Francisco to Los Angeles at a maximum speed of 220 miles per hour. The trip would take two hours and 45 minutes.
